title: Sampling Distribution of a Sample Mean: Standard Deviation
question_text:
Which of the following sample sizes would produce the greatest standard deviation for the sampling distribution of a sample mean?
Assume $\sigma $ is the same for each choice.
solution:
As the sample size increases, the standard deviation decreases. The smallest sample size will yield the greatest standard deviation for the sampling distribution of a sample mean when $\sigma $ is the same.

An analytic approach to this problem is using the formula for the standard deviation for the sampling distribution of a sample mean:

$${ \sigma }_{ \overline { x } }=\dfrac { \sigma }{ \sqrt { n } }$$

You can then make up a value for Ïƒ, say 1, and then substitute the values from the choices in for n and see which choice yields the smallest standard deviation.

Explanation of Distractors

Choices 'B', 'C', 'D', and E are all incorrect as their samples sizes are all greater than 50 which is choice 'A'.
